205. (M.)
Robert Watling
was indicted for
stealing a guinea and a half , the money of
Joseph Connings
, Feb. 4 . ||

Joseph Connings
. I am apprentice to Mr. Wallis, a publican near Grosvenor-square; I had got some money a Christmas-boxing the two last years, so that I had a guinea and a half, and two or three shillings, which was put in an old box, not locked, in the room where the prisoner lay: there was another box stood upon it; I missed it the 4th of this month; he lay alone, only on the Sunday before that, one Megar, a brother soldier of his, lay with him.

John Megar
. The prisoner and I belong to the second regiment of guards; I lay with him in his bed on Sunday night the 31st of January; he had no money to pay his reckoning before we went to bed; the next morning when I awaked, there was a full pot of beer, and another three parts full under the bed; the prisoner told me he brought them up while I was asleep, and that he had paid Mrs. Wallis for it; we got up, and with our breakfast had two pots of beer, which I paid for; then we went down to the water-side to work as usual; going along, he took out a guinea, and tossed it up; I took it in my hand, it appeared to be a new guinea; when we came into the Strand, he called for a pot of beer, and changed it; he had in change half a guinea, a quarter guinea, and I was a halfpenny towards the beer; we went on to Puddle-dock, there he lent me 3 s. to pay a debt; I was to pay him again at 6 d. a week; all the way we went along Thames-street, he treated his acquaintance; I asked him where he had the guinea; he told me he had it out
Joe Sponsey
's box ( a nickname they gave Connings in the house); I said, it will be found out; he said, they might all be d - n'd, they never could, for they could never swear to money.
Prisoner. I did lend him 3 s. at Puddle-dock.

Richard Wallis
. The lad that lost his money is my apprentice, he is a very sober boy; I never saw the money, but I believe he had that money he mentions.
I know nothing at all about it.
Serjeant Murrey. The prisoner has been in the same company I belong to about seven years; he is very sober and honest for what I ever heard; Megar's character is not so fair as the prisoner's.

Serjeant Wilson. I belong to the same company, I never heard any thing amiss of the prisoner; I have known him five years; Megar's character is but very indifferent, I cannot tell whether he may be believed on his oath or not.

Thomas Nelson
. The prisoner was quartered in my house about nine months; he is a hard-working man, and I believe an honest man.
